abstract.p: Letter by former US Atty Robert B Fiske Jr says Sept 15 editorial was unfair in criticizing Judge Jed Rakoff for not recusing himself from lawsuit against Texaco; explains and defends Rakoff's decision (S)

block.p: A Sept. 15 editorial was unfair in its criticism of Judge Jed Rakoff for not recusing himself from a lawsuit against Texaco. You said that he attended a conference that was sponsored by a foundation to which Texaco had made donations and that a former chairman of Texaco was one of the speakers. But you did not note certain important facts in Judge Rakoff's legal opinion explaining his reasons for not recusing himself.

A Sept. 15 editorial was unfair in its criticism of Judge Jed Rakoff for not recusing himself from a lawsuit against Texaco. You said that he attended a conference that was sponsored by a foundation to which Texaco had made donations and that a former chairman of Texaco was one of the speakers. But you did not note certain important facts in Judge Rakoff's legal opinion explaining his reasons for not recusing himself.
The conference was held more than a year after Judge Rakoff had dismissed the case. (It was later remanded to him after the conference.)

Judge Rakoff was unaware that any of the foundation's financing came from Texaco. Moreover, the financial support for this conference came from other charitable institutions not involved in the litigation.
The former chairman of Texaco did not address the merits of the case.
Judge Rakoff's decision not to recuse himself was absolutely correct.
ROBERT B. FISKE JR. New York, Sept. 21, 2000
The writer, a former colleague of Judge Rakoff, was United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, 1976-80.
